Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2012 01:40PM Angela22 wrote: Ms. SillyMama,  thank you so much for your reply.  I'm sorry that you went through that!  I hope you are doing well now.  By the way, your dogs are too cute! It is SO frustrating when the doctors say "don't worry" and the insurance has to "approve" everything.  I keep saying "red tape, more red tape."  I know what you mean by saying "crazy -making."  There are definitely some problems that are causing delays in diagnosing and treatment.  When this is said & done, I am going to try to make some changes.  I work for Quintiles, one of the world's largest Contract Research Organizations.  We manage pharmaceutical clinical trials.  My company may be willing to partner with the American Cancer Society to design and help implement a new standard protocol for any doctor to use when treating a potential breast cancer patient.  Maybe we could call it something like "Ready, Set, Think Pink."  The campaigns for self breast exams & yearly mammograms are pretty effective...but it seems like when we find a lump, some doctors/insurance companies are dropping the ball.  Perhaps a one page laminated simple guideline from the ACS with signs/symptoms & their recommendations on imaging studies/bx.  I know not all docs need this, but I've read where some women didn't get dx for 2 YEARS after finding the lump...somebody needs some help.  I think it would be necessary to educate insurance companies and the doctors' office staff who submit ins approvals on the importance of expedited procedure approvals.  Also important to work with hospitals to manage block time, so that there is adequate dedicated time for the breast surgeons to perform biopsies in the OR.  My appointment with the oncologist was Aug 2nd, but she didn't have block time in the OR available until today, Aug 31st.  Oh, I've got my wheels turning!  :)   I too have a gut feeling this is cancer.  If its not, I will be happily surprised.  Our govenor of NC, Beverly Perdue once said (talking about hurricaines) "Prepare for the worst and hope for the best."  But I've never felt anything this "wrong" in my body before.  At first, the lump was totally non-tender.  Months later it became painful, then the ribs.  Doctors say, "don't worry, painful is a good sign."  But from what I've read on this website, many women had pain before they were diagnosed.  I think the ACS should revise the "symptoms list" so that doctors will not have that thought process and dismiss many women based on that criteria.  And with you, the lump was mobile...doctors say mobile is also a "good thing"...making my point about misconceptions from providers which cause delays in dx & treatment.  I had the excisional biopsy/lumpectomy done this am.  She took out the whole mass.  It had grown to about 4" x 1.5" (yes, I mean inches, not cm).  Thankfully it was at the lowest part of my breast (kind of centered at 6 o'clock).  I have large breasts (D cup) and my left breast was slightly larger than the right before...so now, the right side is slightly larger.  She did a good job. The worst part is waiting for the path report.  She said it could be Tuesday, due to the holiday.  :(  But, I am going to try to relax and enjoy my family.  I hope all you ladies have a great weekend.  May God bless you & keep you. Big hugs to you too, Angela
Posts.Title: Mistake happened with first biopsy, need lumpectomy to diagnose Angela22 Angela22

Posts.Content: Angela22 wrote:  I found a non-tender about 1"x1.5" lump @ 7 o'clock in my left breast Nov 2011.  My GYN doc could feel it & sent me for a MG/US right away.  It showed nothing, so we repeated MG/US in Jan 2012.  Again, it showed nothing, but the lump got larger & I saw a BS.  The BS said it was nothing to worry about & follow-up if it got larger.  It did get larger (actually almost doubled!) & started being painful.  My ribs near the lump became painful.  I also lost about 15 pounds.  So in May 2012, the BS did a FNA.  His nurse called & said "Everything is fine.  It was benign."  I didn't know what to think because I still hurt, couldn't even sleep on my left side.  I saw my PCP, who told me I may have Tietze syndrome.  Now, not only are the ribs directly under the lump affected, but my left 3rd rib is very swollen at the sternum, so much so that you can see it protruding from my chest.  It feels like it is going to break!  And there is a spot under my left shoulder blade that hurts so bad.  Sometimes it hurts to take a deep breath.  So I went to a BS who specializes in breast oncology for a SECOND OPINION.  She had sent for a copy of the pathology report from May.  To our surprise...the report DID NOT say the FNA was benign!  The pathologist made a comment that he "could not make an accurate diagnosis without a second sample, due to the lack of evaluable cells on the slides."  I was so mad!  So we still do not know the diagnosis of this lump yet.  Now I am scheduled to get a lumpectomy at the hospital by the oncologist BS at the end of this week.  She plans to send the sample for permanent pathology instead of frozen sections.  she said that sometimes frozen sections give false negative results, so we want to be 100% sure of the diagnosis this time.  I just hope to find out what is going on & get properly treated.  I once read that "the best lump is a lump in a jar" and I agree.  Also, I know that no doctor can tell you with 100% accuracy that a lump is NOT cancer without a biopsy.  Since my body is telling me something is wrong...I am going to listen.   Surgery 8/31/2012 Lumpectomy: Left Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Mistake happened with first biopsy, need lumpectomy to diagnose Angela22 Angela22

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2012 10:16AM Angela22 wrote: Thank you for the encouragement Angie. And Beesie, thank you too for the information & support. Although I am a nurse, I have no experience in breast oncology and this is my first time dealing with this personally. So it is very helpful to get advice from someone who has "been there, done that". The doc who did the FNA is a Board Certified General Surgeon, specialized in breast surgery. The second opinion oncology BS shares your thoughts about the FNA vs core biopsy. She thinks this lump should have been biopsied correctly in May, but said "all we can do is move forward from here." Please say a little prayer for me on Friday. Thanks again!
Posts.Title: Mistake happened with first biopsy, need lumpectomy to diagnose Angela22 Angela22

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2012 08:03PM Angela22 wrote: I was happily surprised to hear that the pathology report came back benign.  My doctor said it was microcytic hyperplasia, so it is a good thing we took it out now.  She thinks the rib pain is a separate issue and I have an appt to see my PCP tomorrow am.  I'm still loosing weight, no appetite, kinda nauseous, terrible pain, I'm feeling little lumps/bumps along a couple of ribs that I don't know what that is.  I suppose this could be Tietze, but it is terrible.  I can't take NSAIDs, which is the standard treatment for that.  :(  I'm in a pickle!
Posts.Title: Mistake happened with first biopsy, need lumpectomy to diagnose Angela22 Angela22
